dialogue.raw_text: We're not sure. She's been to all kinds of doctors in the city and they've said different things. Some of 'em are callin' it -- (wants to get this right)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Epstein-Barr virus, and the rest are callin' it... Chronic Fatigue Symptom...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Syndrome... Chronic Fatigue Syndrome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it -- syndrome. So you know all about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... a little. There's a lot of debate about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I got that. Some people think it's all in their heads. (more intense) It's been so bad she's had to move back here to Mumford and live with us. And I'm not sure that's the best thing, either...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... a lot of things. Several different factors. Will you see her, Doctor Mumford?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. Why don't you bring her up to my office at 3 tomorrow afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure she'll come. She's in a mood. Do you ever go to somebody's house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Generally that doesn't work out so well. It sends the wrong message to people who need to make a change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mumford is walking up the busy sidewalk carrying his new 5- foot stepladder hooked on his shoulder. Folks greet him. Suddenly Lionel appears in front of Mumford, who stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford continues up the street. We STAY WITH Lionel, who watches Mumford with a sour look, then turns to enter a small medical building.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Lionel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got to have the right ladder for the job. You don't know what you're doing, you can get yourself in trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right, as usual. See you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DELBANCO'S OFFICE - DAY DR. ERNEST DELBANCO, a middle-aged psychiatrist with longish, vanity hair, and PHYLLIS SHEELER, a psychologist in her thirties, sit on the doctor's comfortable furniture, listening. The remains of their take-out lunch is on the coffee table. They seem a little impatient with their as-yet- unseen visitor -- LIONEL (O.S.) ...completely inappropriate and highly unprofessional. Now I don't want to presume to tell you how to run your businesses -- SHEELER -- practices. Lionel is sitting across the room, making an ardent case -- LIONEL -- Whatever. Six months ago, you two were the only games in town. The value of your... (mocking) ..."practices" could be seriously undermined by this bozo. A town this size has only so many headcases to go around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delbanco and Sheeler exchange a look; they find Lionel distasteful.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What exactly would you have us do, Lionel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Protect your turf! Check this guy out. I smell a rat, I tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Dillard, I'm sure Dr. Delbanco shares my gratitude for your concern. But I also know he'd agree that you misunderstand the nature of our calling to mental health. We're not in some... widget business, trying to crush our competition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell's a widget?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DELBANCO'S OFFICE - DAY Lionel comes out of the office, miffed, and goes down the stairs. A moment later, the door opens slightly and Delbanco peeks out to make sure Lionel is gone. He closes the door on us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DELBANCO'S OFFICE - DAY Delbanco stands at the door looking across the room at Sheeler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So does she.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What an asshole!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (agrees) Ernest, what do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think he's got a point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Idyllic. The beautifully manicured field is surrounded by lush woods. Standing about forty feet apart, Mumford and Skip are alone on the field throwing a baseball back and forth. For quite a while the only sounds are the birds, the wind, and the regular SLAP of ball into glove. Finally -- SKIP This is great!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... SLAP.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is exactly what I wanted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ... SLAP.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford considers. SLAP... SLAP... SLAP.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford gestures off in the one direction we have not yet seen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Skip, you must have lots of people you can throw a ball with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd be surprised. Most guys have kids or wives or girlfriends. They're busy. It's not as easy as you think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Skip, you're the head of the whole deal here. Are they busier than you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you know... that's the thing. Like I said, just about everybody in town works for me. And it's just not the same asking someone to throw a ball when they work for you. It's like an order or something... And no one -- no one -- asks me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, would you say we're out here... let me think how to put this... Is your problem really that you're... lonely?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you like this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell yes, I like it. What's better than this? Most guys would kill just to have someone do this with them whenever they like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay then. (SLAP... SLAP) Have you got a lot of friends?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ("nope") Lily and I talk a bit. You know Lily, runs the coffee shop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... I've seen her. Good-looking woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (agrees) She's probably ten years older than you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (SLAP... SLAP) Good-looking woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lives downstairs from me. She's got a great dog named for Danny Ainge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sparks to that) Really? I'm the only person I know that likes Danny Ainge, outside of Celtic fans. Maybe Phoenix.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, there's Lily.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you know that Danny Ainge was drafted by the Blue Jays? Do you know what kind of athlete you have to be to play in the NBA and in the bigs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Amazing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unbelievable... (SLAP... SLAP) ...And Lily named her dog after him? Far out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of person do you have to be to do this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This -- CUT TO:
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : The baseball diamond is sitting in the vast, lush grounds behind the PANDA MODEM WORLD HEADQUARTERS, a brand new, distinctively original, high-tech office park. Wherever there is an opportunity for tasteful signage, it is in the motif of a Giant Panda -- sweet white face, black eyes and ears, round body. Skip is suddenly self-conscious, embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford takes that in. SLAP... SLAP.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skip is a little surprised to hear this from Mumford, but he just throws the ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skip is fascinated, but a little uncomfortable. Mumford seems oblivious, unusually talkative -- MUMFORD Of course, it's not that simple. There's something powerful going on there. We've got a lot of work to do. (announcer voice) It's hit to the warning track! For the first time, Mumford throws the ball way high, like a long fly ball. Skip, delighted as a dog, takes off running and just barely catches it on the run. He pegs it back to Mumford.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I would've traded any of it to have made the Mumford High varsity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I guess Henry Follett is a patient of yours. He's my pharmacist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. (SLAP... SLAP) Guy's got some serious sex fantasies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pretty good, too. Lots of detail. Nothing hard core. Old-fashioned ones, from back when people cared about atmosphere and character.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Problem is, his fantasy life's a lot better than his real one. Nothing can live up to it. His wife got sick of it and left him. Took his kids with her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wondered what happened to her...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In these fantasies, Henry Follett is played by a handsome guy with biceps. Can you imagine that? Where your self-esteem has to be? (throws him the ball) Man, I'd just like to move the guy to the point where he gets to appear in his own fantasies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Silence. Nessa sits staring at Mumford defiantly, an unlit cigarette in her mouth. Mumford looks at the clock -- 3:00 -- and stands up, session over. Nessa quickly lights her cigarette with the lighter concealed in her hand and stands up too. She exhales a huge cloud of smoke and walks quickly to the back door of the office, which Mumford has opened for her, and goes out. Mumford waves half-heartedly at the cloud of smoke as he walks to the door to the waiting room and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : As the door swings open, the first figure we see is Mr. Cook; he twists around at the sound of the door. He acknowledges Mumford and then sighs as he steps aside to reveal, sitting exhausted in a chair, his daughter -- SOFIE -- a young woman whose actual appearance is somewhat disguised at present by her wan, ashen visage. She regards Mumford with some resignation. Her father helps her out of the chair. Sofie keeps her eyes on Mumford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON Mumford, watching her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mr. Cook is gone. Sofie is sitting up on the couch, facing Mumford. She looks like she might pass out at any moment, but her voice is stronger than you'd expect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A joke. Mumford smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's taken all her energy to say this and she sinks down a bit into the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sees something in his face and suddenly laughs -- it's a weak but magical sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford is knocked off balance -- she's right. She saw him clearly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofie suddenly looks defeated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofie gives him a long look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford just smiles. He doesn't want to tell her the truth -- everything.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Feel free to lie down. Most people do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd better not, I'll fall right to sleep. I think it's too soon for me to be sleeping with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What can you tell me about this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, lord. It's almost too exhausting to tell you... (tiny smile, to herself) ...about my exhaustion. I didn't really want to come. I'm not hopeful right now. But I couldn't take the look on my dad's face. He's a truly kind person, which is pretty extraordinary if you knew the story. He's the opposite of me, I guess -- all stamina and resolve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When did you start to feel this way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About six months ago, I guess it is now. God, it seems like years. What a bore! I'm embarrassed by it. Before this happened -- when I'd hear people talk about this kind of thing -- I thought it was a bunch of bullshit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think that now! You think it's a bunch of hooey, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unconvincing) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw it. I saw it in your eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's okay. Maybe it is. My mother always says -- "Everything that's wrong with you is in your head." I suppose that's true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Back when this started, was there anything unusual happening in your life? A change of job, of living situation... a loss of some kind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... but it started one year to the day after my divorce became final. That's not too suspicious, is it?... But it wasn't like I was feeling bad about the divorce. Just the opposite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmm? Is that a professional opinion?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmm, as in -- that's interesting. Sometimes, with enough clues, it's possible to figure these things out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even if you don't think it's real?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what's real and what isn't. That's never been my strong suit. But if you're tired all the time and you've had to give up the life you were having and come back home when you didn't want to... that's worth trying to fix. Maybe I can help you do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What would you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We... we would try several things. But I need to see you a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. I barely made it today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll come to you. We'll try a little walking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll take it slow. You'll never feel you can't handle it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think I can afford it. I don't want my dad paying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll work it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have the best answer for everything. (Mumford shrugs) You seem so... hopeful. Are you always this sunny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one ever thought so. You must bring it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it contagious? 'Cause everyone agrees my immune system's way down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you'll catch it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I ask you something? (Mumford: of course) Didn't you tell my dad you didn't think it was a good idea to come to the patient? (he admits it) So what changed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A taxi drops Mumford in front of the Brockett's large and beautiful house, which sits on an isolated lot on the outskirts of town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Althea leads Mumford toward the back of the lavishly appointed house. The weird thing, what gets in the way of the decor, is the cardboard boxes of all sizes which are stacked everywhere. Many are unopened, but the rest are spilling their styrofoam-nugget and bubble-wrap guts to reveal some hint of their contents: a huge variety of catalogue-ordered housewares, clothing, linens, gadgets, and knickknacks. If it can be ordered from an upscale catalogue (and everything can), it is here. Althea sounds very nervous, cheery.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: HALLWAY TO BACK VERANDA, BROCKETT HOUSE

dialogue.raw_text: sorry everything's in such an uproar. Lots of big occasions coming up, and of course Christmas is only eight months away -- (giggles uncontrollably)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what's keeping Jeremy. You know he stays in the city three nights a week -- I guess I explained that... (Mumford nods) ...I know Katie's here, but I'm not so sure about Martin... I'm making dinner myself tonight, so I'll have to leave you, I'm afraid...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They come out onto the wide porch, which commands a spectacular view of the surrounding countryside. There's an elaborate bar cart out here, which Althea points Mumford toward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She disappears inside with a bang of the screen door. Mumford gets a drink for himself, taking in the view. He sees something out there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm awful I know, but will you please help yourself. I just got a new copper sauciere from Williams-Sonoma and I'm afraid it'll be the death of us all if I don't get back in there...

direction.raw_text: : Way in the distance, coming out of the woods and down toward the house is a teenage boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford turns to see that Althea's thirteen year old daughter KATIE has silently appeared. Her jeans and little tee-shirt are meant to be sexy; it seems sad on her. Mumford nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford follows as she disappears around the corner of the porch.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You're the doctor, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be Katie. People call me Doc.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (motioning urgently) C'mere. Quick... c'mon!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mumford follows Katie into a gloomy hall from a side entrance. Here too, the walls are lined with boxes. She tiptoes to one of two facing doors and waits for him. When he has joined her, she motions him back a foot for safety, then carefully opens the door to a large walk-in closet. Katie's caution becomes understandable: the space is packed so fully and chaotically with catalogue item cartons that it might come tumbling out the door with one careless move. Katie closes the door, then pirouettes to the opposing door, which she swings open freely -- REVEALING: what was once a study is now completely filled with hundreds of cartons, in an infinite variety of shapes and sizes. Mumford is taken aback. Katie points at packages and speaks in a hypnotic WHISPER -- KATIE Cuddledown... Linen & Lace... Scully & Scully... Smith & Hawken... Plow & Hearth... Museum of Modern Art... Smithsonian Museum... J. Crew... Wolferman's... Hold Everything... Nieman Marcus... Coldwater Creek... Garnett Hill... Norm Thompson... Victoria's Secret... Sharper Image... Hammacher Schlemmer...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just as Mumford and Katie come back around the corner, MARTIN, Althea's sixteen year old son, crosses the yard and comes up onto the porch. He's wearing an old black leather jacket with a lot of zippers, dirty jeans and black Converse All- Stars that are coming apart. In his hand, casually but properly held, is a .22 caliber rifle. He looks Mumford over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford takes them both in and nods. He understands. Suddenly, their manner changes, for the worse. What they can see that Mumford cannot is JEREMY BROCKETT, Althea's husband, who has come to the back screen door, with the bustle of a late arrival.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seeing Mumford, Jeremy steps out onto the porch to shake his hand. Jeremy is quite handsome and a fantastic dresser; his Armani outfit cost $4200 all in. His tone: hearty and strained -- JEREMY You must be Dr. Mumford of Mumford. Jeremy Brockett.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeremy goes inside. Martin and Katie exchange a look with each other, then to Mumford. Martin goes inside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is this him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) I showed him.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, kids. Oh, hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doc. Nice to meet you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry I'm late... traffic was a motherfucker. Have another drink, I'll be back in five.

direction.raw_text: . Dinner is over. Jeremy comes out onto the veranda carrying two Cuban cigars. His casual outfit is as stylish and pricey as his work outfit. He joins Mumford and Althea, who immediately gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes inside. The men each have a snifter of cognac. Jeremy makes a ceremony of cutting the cigars -- JEREMY I think you'll like this. Know much about Cuban cigars?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeremy puts the cigars down, pulls a joint out of his cashmere pullover and fires it up. After exhaling a huge cloud of smoke, he offers the joint to Mumford, who declines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeremy takes another hit on the joint and puts it down. He gives a cigar and his gold lighter to Mumford, who begins to light up -- JEREMY Just hold the flame a little bit below the end... that's it... now just turn it slowly as you draw... Mumford does as he's told. Jeremy lights his own cigar.

direction.raw_text: The marijuana is kicking in now -- Jeremy gets a self- satisfied, condescending look on his face that no straight mind would dare. His response includes their lavish immediate surroundings--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeremy blows cigar smoke into his snifter, then takes a mouthful of cognac, savoring the sensations. Mumford watches, fascinated by this guy.

direction.raw_text: Jeremy gives him a look, as if to say "duh."

direction.raw_text: Mumford looks at him a long time.

dialogue.raw_text: Nope.

direction.raw_text: we SEE IMAGES FROM HIS PAST, all FROM MUMFORD'S POV. We do not see him in the scenes. Instead, everyone else in the scene RELATES TO THE CAMERA AS MUMFORD, even if they're just ignoring him.

direction.raw_text: FAST (MUMFORD'S CHILDHOOD POV) toward the back door of a rundown, little house in a poor mining community. We reach the back door and bang inside -- INT. MUMFORD'S CHILDHOOD HOME - MAGIC The cramped interior is grimy and depressing. MUMFORD'S MOTHER worse for wear, has just put a glass of liquor on the sink and returned her attention to the smoking stovetop. She glances briefly at Mumford and greets him pleasantly, clearly drunk. Suddenly, her attention shifts and we -- PAN TO THE FRONT DOOR which is opened roughly by MUMFORD'S FATHER, a coal miner whose face still shows the grime of his work. But it's his scary scowl that impresses. His eyes take in his wife (and her drink) but he says nothing. He barely gives Mumford a glance as he drops his lunch pail on the table and disappears into another room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on slick, glossy magazine pages: each change of image is punctuated by the AMPLIFIED SNAP of the page being turned, like a gunshot. Whether the images are ads or fashion spreads or celebrity candids, the look is the same -- jaded, hip, disinterested, apathetic, either impossibly buff or anorexic, but always severely beautiful. The PAGE TURNING starts at a fevered pitch and becomes even more intense. Finally -- MUMFORD (V.O.) What is it, Nessa? The IMAGES CONTINUE.

direction.raw_text: is revealed as Follett opens the flaps. There is an inner, brown paper wrapping upon which has been set a low-rent catalogue: "METROPOLITAN COLLECTIBLES -- Periodicals, Erotica, Adult Nostalgia." Follett lifts away the wrapping -- There are perhaps a dozen men's magazines of the late fifties and early sixties: Nugget, Adam, The Adam Reader, Swank, Dude. Plus several cartoon collections: Sex to Sexty, Stag Humor. Plus trashy adult novels of the era, with provocative illustrations on the covers: Night Call Nurse, The Neighbors Have No Curtains, Secretarial Sluts, etc. Finally, two video tapes, both of Russ Meyer films: MUDHONEY and COMMON-LAW CABIN. We stay CLOSE ON the contents of the box as Follett's hands shuffle through it, rapidly flipping through the pages. Very soft-core by today's standards, the common thread is clear: voluptuous, heavy-breathing sirens in tight clothes (and out of them) tempting muscular, he-man drifters or libidinous businessmen. A world of lusty secretaries, siren babysitters, and frustrated, neglected wives. In other words, exactly the erotic ambience of Follett's fantasies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (PRESENT) DAY Mumford sits beaming at Henry Follett on the couch. Mumford's glance takes in the clock and he stands up, signalling the end of the session. Follett snaps out of his revery and gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford, surprisingly, takes Follett's hand and shakes it vigorously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford stops him with a "don't mention it" gesture. Follett accepts and goes out the back door. Mumford is pleased someone still wants to use that door. Mumford returns to his desk and begins reading some papers when he HEARS the entry door to the waiting room. Not expecting anyone, he checks the clock, then goes to his office door and opens it. Sofie is standing there, very agitated, just about to knock. She peers past him to see if he's alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofie sits on the couch. Mumford sits in his chair, facing her. Her voice is as strained as her manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford considers a long moment, several scenarios racing through his mind. Finally, carefully -- MUMFORD Is it something you've heard about me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofie suddenly finds it difficult to look into his eyes, she looks around frenetically for a moment. Then, indicating the couch -- SOFIE May I? Mumford gestures "of course." Sofie swings her legs up and lies on the couch so they can no longer see each other's face. (It's the most vigorous movement she's yet shown us.) This seems to help Sofie a bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford appears frozen in his chair. There is a heavy silence in the room. Sofie does not look back there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, Sofie's voice cracks. She is starting to cry, but refuses to acknowledge it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mumford doesn't know what to say. He's on the rack. Finally -- MUMFORD Yes. Silence. Then Sofie gets up, wiping at tears with the back of her bare hand. Mumford jumps up to offer her a tissue, but she ignores it. She will not meet his gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofie turns to go out through the waiting room, but after a step, she stops, pirouettes and goes out the back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right... I'm going to come right out and say this, because that's what your shrink is for, right, so you can tell him what's bothering you?

dialogue.raw_text: Um-huh.

dialogue.raw_text: (tone still rough) First of all, I have been feeling much better lately. I don't know if the syndrome is over -- if it's just run its course or something -- but I feel a hundred per cent better than when I first came to you.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Given that, I'm obviously not going to be judging things in the most realistic way.

dialogue.raw_text: I don't follow you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) I'm saying that since I'm doing so much better -- which I attribute to you -- I'm liable to misinterpret some of my feelings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tentative) Okay...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The point is this -- I am not a blank page. I did not just fall off the turnip truck. Do you know what I mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know a little about psychology. I took three different courses in college. It's true, none of them were above the two hundred level, but I took them... And there was one concept I remember very well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Transference!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Transference.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, and that is what I have got right now. I have taken my feelings of gratitude... and relief... and transferred them onto... you. I have taken all those warm, grateful emotions and confused them with feelings for you... So that now I am under the delusion... (a deep breath) ...that I am in love with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you can understand why I have some serious questions about your methods. I mean, obviously it becomes much more likely that I'm going to have confusion about this when your idea of treatment is to go walking in the woods and up to make- outs-ville and do all these highly romantic activities --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We had a paper route together, for godssake! Do you understand how I might be a little resentful? Knowing that this so-called "love" I'm feeling is totally bogus, and just a pathetic case of... transference?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you ought to think about how you're going to fix this. And when you do... (suddenly losing her will) ...please get back to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue
